Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity for Computer Science Teaching in a Rural State

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing computer science teachers who can support high school students in being successful in rigorous, academic computer science courses is a national need, particularly in rural communities. This project aims to permanently increase the capacity of the state of Maine to offer high quality computer science instruction. The STEM-C (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics, including Computing) Partnerships program supports research-driven partnerships between STEM experts and K-12 school systems to bring about institutional change for better STEM education at the K-12 level. This STEM-C Partnerships Computer Science Expansion project builds on a previously successful Partnership and now works to infuse high quality computer science curriculum and teaching into high schools across Maine. Over a three-year period, this Partnership will support seventy-five current teachers of mathematics in becoming computer science teachers. The Partnership supporting this project is comprised of the Maine Mathematics and Science Alliance, the University of Maine at Augusta, and Regional School Unit RSU #26 (Orono, Maine), with support from the Maine Department of Education, the University of California Los Angeles Exploring Computer Science project, the Computer Science Teachers' Association, the IEEE K-12 STEM Literacy Committee, and industry partners.

Curriculum will be developed to train mostly current teachers of mathematics so that they will be able to offer the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) course to high school level students. This ECS course will be developed around Maine employers and the ways in which computer science is used across sectors in the state of Maine, including Axiom Technologies, Mount Desert Island Biological Laboratory, Jackson Laboratory, Kepware Technologies, and L.L.Bean. A Computer Science Teaching Methods course will be developed and made available online through the University of Maine at Augusta. The project will build knowledge through its research effort related to the following question: How can industry examples of computer science principles support teachers' ability to apply these principles to relevant contexts? Moreover, the work of the Partnership will result in the development of a model for rural states to sustainably provide computer science professional development, as well as give rise to institutionalization of a rigorous in-service training course for prospective computer science teachers. The project evaluation contains formative and summative evaluation of teacher impact and partnership growth. Major contributions of this project include: a) informing the statewide process of examining technology and mathematics curricula and considering ways to incorporate computer science in those curricula; b) significantly increasing the capacity of the state to offer computer science statewide; and c) potentially inspiring new models for workplace-based curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was an attempt to build capacity in computer science education by providing teacher professional development and other supports for the introduction of computer science into curricula across Maine, the most rural state in the nation. Prior to the beginning of this project, only 33 teachers of computer science were readily identified, mostly in the southern half of the state.

Over three years, a total of 54 teachers in school districts all across the state received professional development at a week-long summer institute (summers of 2015, 2016 and 2017) and four additional Saturday sessions. In addition, they participated in our research to tie computer science principles to real-world local businesses in rural communities.

Our research evolved over the course of the three years, as we explored different approaches to meeting our goal. In 2015 we tried to connect computer science principles with local businesses by modifying existing published lesson plans with hands-on components. Finding these redundant with the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum and not particularly engaging, we shifted the model in 2016 to making short videos that demonstrated ECS learning objectives through interviews with local business employees. These were found to be more engaging by students, and were easier to integrate into the ECS curriculum while still being accessible. We also learned that youth identified more with 'hyper-local' businesses in their own towns, rather than larger iconic companies that exist in the urban parts of the state. In the final iteration, and through supplemental funding in 2018-19,  we supported 11 teachers across three states (Maine, Vermont, and Wyoming) to work with student teams as they produced their own videos highlighting computer science principles in businesses in their local communities.

Below are some student comments, in their own writing, and a teacher comment about the project:

  •  Why I chose the before to 2 is cause I was not intersted when we started computer science, I thought that it wasn't important. I chose 6 for after is cause when we started getting into computer science it started getting more interested for me and i was wrong what i thought, it is important in your life cause you will have job that has computer science. - 6th grader
  • I always knew computer science was an option and considered it somewhat, but after this project I found myself really engaged in everything about computer science. - 8th grader
  • They certainly were drawn to things that they were familiar with. They were much more excited about their own ideas than mine. Mainly, you know, they were drawn to the things they thought they had a connection to; even like a car wash in town, you know. The things they came up with were far more tantalizing than the things that I came up with. - teacher

Project staff supported teachers in working with students, and particularly in convincing some teachers to facilitate rather than control the process. Letting students take the lead was a piece of advice we would recommend for future cohorts. Also, frequent reminders had to be given to both teachers and students that the project goal was not to produce a highly polished video, nor was it simply to characterize how technology is used in people's jobs.

Overall, we were able to use low-cost and readily available materials (e.g., smartphones and free editing software) to increase accessibility and support teachers in the technical aspects of storyboarding, interview techniques, and basic videography. Within our small sample, we found that the students learned about computer science principles, local business, and working as a team in what became a project-based learning activity.

The videos created by students in the final project phase can be viewed at https://mmsa.org/projects/exploring-computer-science/mmsa-video-showcase/
